Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Transgender and nonbinary Americans are facing new laws and rules that effectively prohibit them and others from obtaining documentation like birth certificates and driver’s licenses that align with their gender identities.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Transgender and nonbinary Americans are facing new laws and rules that effectively prohibit them and others from obtaining documentation like birth certificates and driver’s licenses that align with their gender identities.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Some trans voters have expressed confusion and fear of discrimination at the ballot box that could discourage them from participating in public life.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Some trans voters have expressed confusion and fear of discrimination at the ballot box that could discourage them from participating in public life.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Regulations around gender impact cisgender people, particularly women and women of color.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Cisgender people, particularly women and women of color
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Regulations around gender impact cisgender people, particularly women and women of color.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: In states that require voters to “reasonably resemble” the picture on their ID, like North Carolina and Wisconsin, the results could ensnare anyone at the ballot box who doesn’t fit the binary concept of masculinity and femininity traits.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Anyone at the ballot box who doesn’t fit the binary concept of masculinity and femininity traits
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: In states that require voters to “reasonably resemble” the picture on their ID, like North Carolina and Wisconsin, the results could ensnare anyone at the ballot box who doesn’t fit the binary concept of masculinity and femininity traits.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Black and Hispanic people are among those most likely not to have a current license, so the requirement harms them too, regardless of their gender identity.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Black and Hispanic people are among those most likely not to have a current license, so the requirement harms them too, regardless of their gender identity.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: In many red states, Republican-led attacks on transgender people are going hand-in-hand with new identification requirements and other laws that pose barriers to the ballot that reach beyond gender lines.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: In many red states, Republican-led attacks on transgender people are going hand-in-hand with new identification requirements and other laws that pose barriers to the ballot that reach beyond gender lines.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Since 2020, many Republican-controlled states have passed laws expanding the authority of those temporary election observers who work elections under certain rules and may feel compelled to stop someone from voting under the guise of stopping widespread election fraud, which has been repeatedly debunked.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Since 2020, many Republican-controlled states have passed laws expanding the authority of those temporary election observers who work elections under certain rules and may feel compelled to stop someone from voting under the guise of stopping widespread election fraud, which has been repeatedly debunked.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Trans people turned out to vote despite those policy roadblocks.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Trans people turned out to vote despite those policy roadblocks.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: At least nine states in the past two years have explicitly regulated gender in this way, according to a tally by the Movement Advancement Project (MAP), which tracks LGBTQ+ policy.
Document Sources.Source Justification: According to a tally by the Movement Advancement Project (MAP), which tracks LGBTQ+ policy.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Document Sources.Source Justification: According to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Document Sources.Name of Source: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law
Document Sources.Source Justification: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification. “There is an unsafe and intimidating environment around existing as trans in society, and definitely in being able to go to the polls safely and cast a ballot.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “A lot is falling on poll workers to correctly enforce the law,” Kunis added. “And I would argue that is less of a solid protection in states where anti-trans rhetoric is skyrocketing.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund. “I think the big takeaway is that our community is really trying to come out and make a difference through the democratic process.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID. And so when a state goes out of its way to enforce its message about its belief about sex and gender on a license, and transgender people then have to publicize that when they show other people, it creates a dangerous environment,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn, an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The states with the anti-trans laws are also the ones that are more likely to be passing anti-voter laws, full stop,” Kunis said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said. “And really to scare trans folks from even participating and getting the license if they needed to update it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “With these laws in Florida, you’re forced to choose between living authentically and just not really participating in public life,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I can imagine that a lot of trans folks in Florida who might not have access … to an accurate and affirming ID might not want to engage in that process at all, especially in such a heightened political environment,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “That’s when you’re gonna see the convergence of those two elements. It really seems like it would only result in more discrimination, more discomfort for trans people, more interrogation and potentially just being turned away.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They won’t stop me, but I can see how it would stop others,” she said. “It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs, a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Our ability to participate in this democracy in Florida, it’s been on the line for a while,” Diaz said. Transgender people, they said, are being “forced to choose between participating in our greatest civic right or just sitting out because the state doesn’t see us for who we are.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Something that’s very frustrating for us at VoteRiders is you will never be able to capture the number of people who do not feel safe voting, and who therefore stay home. And you also won’t be able to capture the people who are trans and show up to try and vote and are turned away.” Kunis said. “And we know that is happening, but it is difficult to quantify.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are definitely the physical dangers, the dangers for harassment, discrimination — but also ultimately, voter suppression,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn, an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It really shows the resiliency of the trans community to ensure that our voices are heard and we have visibility at the ballot box,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of voting and elections for the group that conducted the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Josie Caballero, director of voting and elections for the group that conducted the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There’s nothing these laws will do to stop me from living my best life,” she said. “It just puts my energy and passion towards making this place better for me and other trans people.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs, a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Kansas, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In eight battleground states, the nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The ACLU sued the agency for discrimination, claiming the rule was adopted illegally because it didn’t follow proper administrative procedure.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU sued the agency for discrimination, claiming the rule was adopted illegally because it didn’t follow proper administrative procedure.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules, has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules, has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: VoteRiders is conducting year-round voter education.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: VoteRiders is conducting year-round voter education.
